title: 112_s323
content: The "First State National Historical Park Act" establishes the First State National Historical Park in Delaware, with definitions for terms like "historical park" and "Secretary" provided in the Act. The First State National Historical Park is established in Delaware to preserve cultural and historic resources related to early settlements and Delaware's role in ratifying the Constitution. The park will be administered as part of the National Park System once the Secretary determines sufficient land availability. The Secretary determines sufficient land for the historical park, publishes notice in Federal Register, and provides a boundary map. The map is available for public inspection. Historic sites like The Old Sherriff's House may be included within the park's boundary. The Old Sherriff's House in New Castle County, Delaware, Fort Christina National Historic Landmark, Old Swedes Church National Historic Landmark, Old New Castle Courthouse, John Dickinson Plantation National Historic Landmark, Dover Green, and Ryves Holt House are all significant historical landmarks in Delaware. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATION. The Secretary administers the historical park in accordance with applicable laws, including the National Park System Organic Act and the Act of August 21, 1935. They may acquire land through purchase, donation, or exchange, and adjust the park's boundary accordingly. The Secretary is also authorized to provide interpretive tours. The Secretary may provide interpretive tours to sites outside the historical park, including Fort Casimir, DeVries Monument, Amstel House, Dutch House, and Zwaanendael Museum. They can also enter into cooperative agreements to mark, interpret, and restore historic resources within the park, with public access required. The Federal share of the total cost of activities under a cooperative agreement is capped at 50%, with the non-Federal share allowed in the form of in-kind contributions. The Secretary must complete a management plan for the historical park within 3 fiscal years, following applicable laws. The Secretary will conduct a study to assess additional properties in the State for historical significance related to the historical park. The study will consider designating these properties as National Historic Landmarks. Additionally, funds necessary to implement this Act will be authorized.
